text:
I followed the recipe almost exactly.  The only difference I made was to braise the meat in broth for 45 minutes until it was tender, then I added it to the rest of the sauce after I had thickened it with flour.  I didnt want to have to stand over the stove stirring a thickened sauce for 45 min.  I thought this was very good.  It was definitely not the normal beefy flavor that Im used to with beef stroganoff  with the white wine and mustard but it was very good.

country:
None
text:
Marinated beef in red wine, omitted white wine. Used 2 TBS cornstarch and 2 TBS flour instead of 4 TBS flour. Browned beef, than removed from pan to cook onions and garlic, then stirred in broth and flour/cornstarch, added beef back in. Used fresh mushrooms and let them simmer with the beef. Added cream cheese at the end.

text:
I used 1 1/2 lbs of sirlion and it was super tender. I used yellow onion and some leek just out of preference, and added a splash of worsteshire and omitted the white wine since i didnt have any. I dissolved 2 tablespoons of flour and 2 tablespoons of cornstarch in a 14 oz can of beef broth instead of all flour. Turned out good.also used 8 oz fresh mushrooms instead of canned.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Unaltered this is a fantastic recipe.  I harvest wild mushrooms and had some dried ones on hand.  I rehydrated them in hot water being careful to make sure I'd have at least 10 oz of "mushroom water" left over.  I removed the rehydrated mushrooms and added beef bullion to the mushroom water and used that in place of beef broth.  OUT OF THIS WORLD!  Also, because dried mushrooms tend to remain a bit tough, I added them to the mixture at the beginning of the simmer to get them extra cook time.  To up the creaminess you can also add 4 oz of cream cheese.

text:
Amazing, I would never have expected this to be so popular with my finicky family.  Aside from substituting Elk cut into the 1/4 x 2 inch strips, marinated for 1 hour in a 4/1 water-balsamic vinegar, 1T sugar, dried thyme, bay leaf mixture I would not dare change anything.   Mustard who would EVER have thought that could make such a tasty difference.  Thanks Donna, your recipe has helped me immeasurably.

text:
took what I had and used this recipe as a guide:  no chuck, so used ground chuck; no beef broth so I used 1 can Golden Mushroom soup (not diluted); added 1 heaping tbsp minced garlic (the refrigerated kind) and next time I'll use more; used 1 regular onion instead of the green onions; no flour or other thickeners (didn't seem to need it); and closer to a cup and a half of sour cream. I forgot the mustard, but I didn't miss it.  I give 4.5 stars, but since AllRecipes won't let me, I rounded up.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here are my changes: used fresh mushroom...always.  Canned mushrooms taste wierd.  One med/large onion. Instead of 4onces butter I used half butter half olive oil when browning meat bc it doesn't burn as quickly.  Must marinade meet with wine.  Dont add in the end gets too watery.  By doing this it adds so much flavor too meat.  When you add the onion it tastes so much better when you add some fresh garlic as well.  In the end, add about 1/3 C cream cheese(helps thickens too).

text:
This was an awesome recipe.  I vegetarianized it by using two bags of Morningstar crumbles in lieu of the chuck roast.  I also used veggie broth instead of beef broth (I think it would have been even better with mushroom broth but I couldn't find it at the store).  Leftovers were fantastic.  I'm getting a deep freezer later this month, and I think this recipe will freeze beautifully.  I plan to make it along with some rice and put it in some Ziplock Vacuum Seal bags in individual serving sizes.

text:
I made this exactly as is, and found that there is just too much butter. 4 ounces of butter is one whole stick. Still, everyone loved it, especially the guys. I will make it again and use fresh mushrooms and yellow onions and definitely reduce the amount of butter. The chuck was nice and tender, melt in your mouth delicious. My local store carries something called "petite tender steaks" which are simply trimmed chuck steaks which makes this recipe a lot easier to prepare. Chuck does have good flavor and the long simmer does the trick.

text:
We made this tonight and it was really tastey.  I followed many of the suggestions that I had seen in others comments, I added Worcestershire sauce, garlic, and half of a sweet onion instead of the green onions.  I also added a big scoop of the new cooking cream (like cream cheese) along with the sour cream at the end.  I also chopped up the mushrooms (just a personal preference to have lots of smaller bits throughout the dish).  It was great, we served it on egg noodles.  I would definitely make this again.

OMG, this is such a great base recipe!  I actually changed it up a bit only because Trader Joes didn't have all the ingredients, but it was SO delicious.  I too  added cream cheese in addition to sour cream, I substituted in hamburger meat because it looked best at the store, I used fresh mushrooms instead of canned and just added them after the onion, I tossed in some garlic, and dropped out the wine because all I had was a super oaky red, but added Worcestershire Sauce instead.  Well, I guess I did make a lot of changes.  Regardless, I used the same cooking process and it was delicious!  I look forward to making this again following the original recipe to see which is best.

text:
This is such a delicious, simple, and versatile recipe. It has become my generic starting point for an easy stroganoff because it tastes great even when more inexpensive ingredients are used. I've cooked it according to the instructions before, and it was great, but it is also awesome cooked with inexpensive hamburger (be sure to drain some of the fat) and awful, cheap bottle of chardonnay. Overall it is easy, relatively quick to prepare, and inexpensive to make. This recipe deserves its 5 star rating.

text:
I'm a big fan of beef stroganoff-- and this is the best I've ever had. Marinated eye of round roast in straight apple cider vinegar for a couple of hours prior to cooking to use up a cheap cut of meat and to sub for the wine. As the sauce was already too thin, adding wine/vinegar at the end would be a step backwards. Thanks to another reviewer for the tip about tempering by mixing a bit of the hot sauce with the sour cream before adding it to the pot. Thanks, Donna!

text:
Amazing with some purely personal changes. The basic recipe for this is great. I just added some things that I like. Such as using yellow onion instead of green, adding garlic, using fresh mushrooms. I followed other's suggestions and marinated in the wine & some soy sauce first. I browned the meat and added the marinade when cooking the mushrooms, onion, garlic. I think what really makes this dish though is the mustard. I used grey poupon. I also used some cream cheese and the added the sour cream. Thank you so much for this recipe!

text:
OMGolly!  Incredible!  I followed other reviewer's advice and marinated the meat (I used stew meat) in red wine - therefore skipped the white wine at the end of the steps.  Browned the meat in olive oil instead of butter.  Doubled the green onions.  Used Beef Consomme because it's what I had on hand.  Used fresh mushrooms (that I added at the same time I added the beef).  I'm sure the recipe would have been just as yummy even without my changes -- I am just trying to clean out my pantry and use what I have on hand without making extra trips to the grocery store.  Everyone loved -- I will definitely make again!  Thanks for sharing Donna!

text:
Oh wow, this is really good!  Changes I made for what I had on hand:  used leftover eye of round roast made in slow cooker; used about 1/4 of a white onion; omitted wine but added 1 TBSP Worc sauce and 1/4 cup sherry; sauteed garlic with mushrooms and onions;  mixed flour with a little cold water before adding to prevent lumps.  Thanks for fabulous recipe!

text:
Great recipe! I did alter it a bit to fit with the ingredients I had on hand. I used lean burger instead of chuck roast, yellow onion instead of green onion, dry sherry instead of white wine, and corn starch instead of flour. I also used more beef broth since I mixed the pasta in before serving and they soak up a lot of liquid. Oh, and omitted the butter, and added garlic and worchestershire. Turned out great!!

text:
This has become our favorite beef stroganoff recipe. My wife loves when I make this for dinner.  I do marinate the beef in red wine and use 1 white onion as well as 2-3 cloves of garlic. I use an 8 oz container of fresh mushrooms and a container of Pennsylvania Dutch sliced mushrooms. Also add Worcestershire sauce and dijon mustard as well. Finish with 1/3 cup sour cream and 1/3 cup cream cheese.

text:
Pretty good.  I took the suggestion of others and marinated the meat in red wine for about 2.5 hours (a little longer than I meant to) and I think it made the meat toooo wine flavored, which translated into the sauce tasting like wine, so be careful to marinate it a MAX of 2 hours. Overall it was great!  Added about 3 Tblsp. chopped garlic with the onions.  Loved that this recipe doesn't use cans of cream of _______ like other recipes do.  Husband loved it!

Display Name:
Courtney

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I LOVED this recipe!  I followed a few other reviewers and marinated the meat in some white wine with a tablespoon of worcestershire (I drained prior to browning meat).  I only used 2 oz of butter (4 TBSP) to help cut down on fat and it did not affect the flavor at all.  I also added 2 cloves of minced garlic to the onions.  The sauce was a bit thin for my taste so I did end up adding about a tsp of cornstarch mixed with a bit of water to the gravy which worked perfectly.  Added about a 1/2 T of worcestershire to the sauce.  I used sirloin which turned out very tender, but it did require the full hour of simmering.  I also used baby bellas mushrooms which i sauteed separately with a small amt of butter and added at the end with the wine and sour cream.  Added a pinch of nutmeg as well.  My husband has already requested me to make this again and he is not easily impressed.

text:
This is an excellent beef stroganoff; I always cut up a beef chuck roast; (I wait until they go on sale and then stock up) and cut them cube size; one key to this recipe is you need to cook the meat an hour or more so that it is tender; I have made this 4 times and one time I was rushing and only cooked it 30 minutes and the beef was tough; don't be tempted to try to eat it earlier than 1 hour...

text:
AWESOME. Hubby loved it. Added more than a tablespoon of garlic with the onions, marinated the meat in red wine for 4 hours, little more mustard than called for and used stone ground, used 2 tbs flour, 2 tbs cornstarch dissolved in the broth, but ended up putting a little more in with the sour cream to thicken up. Added 1 tbs Worcestershire with the mustard used a regular onion chopped, and added more mushrooms (10 fresh package but will add double that next time. Hubby also says more meat but I thought it was plenty. Added the mushrooms when I put the meat back in the pan to simmer.  YAY! WIll be making again....

text:
I have been using this recipe for over 40 years. It was originally in the Chicago Tribune as Mitch Miller's Beef stroganoff. The only difference is that I use round steak and 1 medium onion. I have found that Sauterne wine is best. Serve it with rice for a different flavor (don't know why). It is one of family's favorite. I include this in recipes for new brides.

This is very good.  I made it in a skillet with 1 lb. ground beef and it was quick and easy.  I browned the ground beef and onions and didn't drain the grease. I also omitted the white wine and it was still great flavor.  Great recipe!

Don't use all the flour.  Use 1 TB and less butter.  It's not necessary to achieve a thick and dreamy sauce.  I added 1 TB fresh chopped dill at the end with the sour cream.  I also used up the cooked leftover prime rib instead of the chuck roast and I used fresh mushrooms.  I simmered everything together for about 50 minutes and it was heaven.

text:
I love this recipe and so does everyone in the family. The flavors are incredible. The only personal touches I make to it are to use sirloin roast for the meat, use a yellow onion instead of the green onions (more as a convenience) and I saute 6-8oz sliced portabella mushrooms with the onion instead of using the canned mushrooms. Serve over egg noodles.

text:
wonderful. i adapted this for my crock pot to make it easier. i also used white onions instead of green and fresh shrooms. i threw the meat, flour, spices(i added garlic and 1Tb paprika), onions and mushrooms in a bowl and mixed. sprayed the crock pot w/ pam. added the meat mixture and the rest of the ingredients except sour cream. cooked on high 3 hrs. then i dropped some fresh pasta dough into the simmering sauce for dumplings. cooked another hour then added the sour cream. i am going to start keeping homemade pasta dough in the freezer just for this recipe.

text:
This is a very good recipe!  The first time I made it I followed the reviewer comments.  The second time I made it I followed more so the original recipe.    It's great with the chuck roast and white wine.  I added 1 tbsp of minced garlic and 1/2 medium onion.    I didn't cook the beef until after I sauteed the mushrooms, garlic and onion.  I seasoned the beef with salt, Lawry's seasoning salt, and lots of ground pepper.  I also added 1 tbsp of Worchestire sauce and only used a capful of white wine versus 1/3 cup.  Great recipe!!!

text:
It tastes good but needs a lot of tweaking. That to me, is a mediocre recipe. The amount of butter in it disturbs me. Like many reviewers, I marinated the beef in red wine and took out the white wine. Saute fresh mushrooms instead of canned. Try adding 8-10 drops of tabasco sauce and a can of tomato soup and half the broth - you may not even need it at all. This will create a sweeter, tastier version of this otherwise unremarkable stroganoff.

text:
This is the real deal.  I have marinated the meat and I have also skipped that step.  I really can't tell too much of a difference.  If you have the time, marinate.  If not, don't worry.  It still tastes great.  I also use a medium onion instead of scallions.  I like to add a few cloves of garlic, too.  But I add garlic to just about everything.  I also add 1 Tbsp of Worcestershire...how can you make Stoganoff without it, right? I also remove the meat after it's browned and then cook the onions.  Then I add the meat back to the pan. I also stir my flour (I have also used cornstarch) into the beef broth to smooth it out before adding it into the pan. I am getting hungry typing this.  "Honey, guess what we're having for dinner tonight?"

text:
We loved this..we usually eat very healthy, but I like to treat my family sometimes so we added all the butter, 1/2c light sour cream and 1/2c light cream cheese, baby bellas which I suggest putting in about 15mins before the end, maybe even sauting first. I used just flour and marinated the beef in red wine, I also added a splash in the sauce at the end, it is ok if it is a little thin so it will mix with the noodles better. My friend joined us for dinner and she said it was the most tender stroganoff she has ever had. It was a delight for us all. Not something I would make all the time because of all the cream and butter. It will absolutely stay in my recipe box.

text:
this is an amazing recipe! My 2 roommates and boyfriend went back for seconds and thirds when I made this for them.  I marinated thin slices (about 1/4 inch) of the chuck roast in red wine, but also added about 1/2 tbsp of cornstarch and fresh minced garlic to the marinade, worked it into the meat with my hands and let it sit in the fridge for about half an hour before searing it.  The meat came out AWESOME - juicy, tender, and full of flavor.  I also added a can of low-fat low-sodium cream of mushroom soup and used regular beef broth for the base.  This was an absolutely fantastic recipe.  Thanks!

I have made this recipe twice now. The first time I did like other reviews suggested and omitted the white wine and used red wine to soak the meat in, along with using 1/2 sour cream and cream cheese for the sauce. The second time I made it like the recipe, or tried. When I added the sour cream and white wine I ended up adding cream cheese to tone down the sharp taste and thicken the sauce. It was still good, but I think I'll stick with the red wine version... awesome flavor! Thanks for the recipe, its a keeper!

text:
I modified the recipe slightly after reading some of the other reviews: Fresh mushrooms sauteed in garlic, yellow onion instead of green , red wine instead of white and then into a crock pot for about 3.5-4 hours on LOW after the initial cooking was completed on the stovetop. Also, I added 1/3 cup sour cream and about 1/3 package of cream cheese. The sauce was still a bit too runny, but the flavor was excellent. Will definitely make this again!

Yummmm soo good.. i used 1 1/2 beef boullion cubes mixed in 1.5 cups water, i had to add 1.5 tablespoons cornstarch to get it to thicken, probably because of not using condensed beef broth, i also added some garlic and pepper and marinated the beef in wine for 3 hours before cooking. text:
This was the first time that I made beef Stroganoff and I absolutely loved it.  I did make the following changes though:  1)I used onions instead of green onions and added two cloves of garlic.  2)  I first fried the onions and garlic and then added the meat to it and fried the meat along with the onions.  3)  I used fresh mushrooms that I sliced.  After frying the meet along with the onion, as natural meat juice came out, I added the mushrooms.  4)  I added a bit more beef broth than the recipe and added Rotini pasta to it and let it cook along with the rest of the food.  5)  I cooked it for a total of 30 min or so-pasta was in it for about 10 mins.
It came out very delicious and I enjoyed it very much.

text:
Outstanding meal. Substituted leftover grilled strip steak. Used 3 cloves fresh minced garlic when browning the meat. Substituted 12 oz. fresh sliced mushrooms and added after cooking onions. Added 1 T Worcestershire with the mustard and stock. The sauce was a bit thick, so I added additional beef stock (1/2 C) and as needed (probably 1 C total). Used a good California Riesling and a bit more sour cream (perhaps a 1/2 C total). Served over buttered egg noodles. My wife and kids raved!

text:
Absolutely delicious beef stroganoff! I used top sirloin roast and marinated it overnight in red wine. If you use a non-stick skillet you can get by with half the butter. After the meat browned, I spooned out most of the excess liquid and had no problem moving the meat aside to cook the onions (hint: chopped white or yellow are less work.) I like extra sauce so I added 1 - 2 c. more broth (made from beef base) than the recipe calls for. Also sauted fresh mushrooms in a little butter and garlic to add at the end...mmmmm!

text:
This is a wonderful recipe! I gave it four stars because I felt I had to add a little more flavour. 1st of all, I used ground beef to save time (skipped the hour of simmering). Second, I skipped the oil and used a non-stick pot. Next, instead of using sour cream I used plain yoghurt (a lot healthier and trust me, it still tastes really good!). I added a little extra wine because I love the flavour it gives, and instead of adding salt, I simply added soy sauce so that the colour looks even more appetizing. YUM!!!!!!

text:
This was a really good recipe as written but with some tweaking you can make it excellent.  I used a large chopped onion (in addition to the green onion), 1 tablespoon of minced garlic, 8 ounces sliced, fresh mushrooms that I added half way thru the cooking time and 1/2 cup fresh chopped parsley added just before serving for flavor and beauty.  Omitted the wine cause I don't drink alcohol and just added water because by the time the meat was tender, it had thickened quite a bit and needed to be thinned a little.  Also, I think slicing the meat into 1 inch slices makes them more bite size. I will be making this again for sure, thanks!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2007-11-13T10:50:01.207
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2520283
Display Name:
Alida Rovetto
isPro:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This was great.  I loved it !!  I tweaked the recipe a  bit.  I used a london broil (all I had).  Sliced it very thin and sauteed it in butter.  I added about 3 medium onions (sliced).  Added 2 cans of low sodium beef broth and 24 ounces of sliced fresh mushrooms.  I also put it in the pressure cooker for 25 minutes.  It made the meat so tender and it took less time.
After I opened the pressure cooker I added 1 tblspoon of cornstarch to 1/2 cup of wine and added a few dashes of Worsceshire sauce.  I also added 1/2 package of onion soup mix.  At the very end I added about 1/2 cup of sour cream.

Served with egg noodles.

This recipe is a keeper.  I love Beef Stroganoff but it never came out flavorful enough.  This was awesome.
Thank You !!

This was good and smelled awesome, but DH asked why it tasted like roast? He didn't care for the chuck roast cut in this. I used canned portabella mushroom pieces and let them cook in for about an hour. My guys devoured this so I know it was good. Thanks Donna, this was really good, but I'll use my tried and true next time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I marinated a chuck roast in balsamic vinegar/water (50/50) in the fridge for 3 hours. Put roast, marinade, and more water in pressure cooker; brought to pressure and cooked for 45 minutes. Removed roast and sliced against the grain.

Sliced and quartered two yellow onions, sliced 1 large package of button mushrooms, 1 bell pepper. Added minced garlic and ground mustard and browned all in large skillet w/olive oil. After veggies wilted I added broth from the pressure cooker, 1 large package of cream cheese and 1/2 container of cream cheese. Served over egg noodles. Very yummy! Will probably use corn starch to thicken gravy leftovers. (Did not need to brown roast or use any salt/pepper) Balsamic vinegar is GREAT! I thought I was being frivolous when I bought it, but it was worth every dollar.

I am giving this 4 stars instead of 5 only because I made modifications while I was going, which isn't new for me.  It's hard for me not to reach into the spice cabinet.  I added about a teaspoon of taragon and about 1 tbs of worsch. sauce.  As it was cooking I added more beef broth as it started to thicken and stick to the pan. Oh, I also used left over filet mignon and portobello mushrooms from Christmas Dinner...it was DELICIOUS!

We loved this.  Made a few changes to make it easier, healthier and cheaper.  Browned ground beef, drained, then returned to pot and cooked with some onion and then garlic. text:
This recipe was great!  I cooked the beef and onions in one skillet, and as it was cooking, I started making the sauce in another large pot on the stove, where I sauteed some fresh sliced mushrooms, then added 2 small cans of cream of mushroom soup.  When the beef was done, I poured off the fat and added the beef to my mushroom sauce.  Then I added the sour cream and wine, and cooked it just a little bit longer to warm it up.  I served it over egg noodles.  The family loved it, and the leftovers were great the next day!  Thanks!

text:
easy and delicious, thanks donna for sharing this receipe.  I made a few changes though:  i used sirloin strips instead of beef chuck; 1 medium yellow onion instead of green onion; i reduced the butter to 2 ounces; cornstarch works as well as flour... i actually disolved the cornstarch in some milk before adding to the pan; i also used 1 package of fresh mushrooms instead of the canned one; and i increased the sour cream to 1 cup.  I added the wine to the beef when i was browning it, and i also plated out the beef instead of pushing aside.

text:
Unbelievably tasty and easy.  The changes I've made:  used fresh mushrooms instead of canned, added 5 gloves of minced garlic, and skipped the wine.  I didn't have beef broth, so I used 1/2 cube of chicken broth mix to season the meat, and 1/2 cube with water to add to the sause.  Turned out wonderful.  Also, next time I'll use 3lb of meat instead of 2.  We're not big sidedish fans, so I ended up having leftover sause.  But that has nothing to do with the taste.  Superb!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/179312.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was truly outstanding.  I sliced top sirloin very thin while it was still slightly frozen, then, as others suggested, marinated the strips in wine for a few hours, omitting the step of adding wine at the end.  I also used organic beef stock instead of the condensed beef broth, and wound up adding about 3 c.  The sauce was still rich and had the perfect consistency.  I don't have a lid for my large skillet, though, so I covered with foil - this may have lead to more evaporation, so I would be careful about adding more liquid if you have a really tight-fitting lid.  I served this with brown basmati, and it was gobbled up.  It was even better the next day.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this a few months ago for the first time & am making again tonight.  (Was getting tired of making the same old things after being married for 30 + years).  Was a little nervous trying something new, but to my surprise, my husband liked it!  I had to scale  down to 4, since it was only for the 2 of us! 

After reading all of the reviews, I decided to take their advice &
marinade in red wine in fridge for a couple of hours, use 1/2 corn starch & 1/2 flour & mix it in w/the broth before putting in the pan, used yellow onions.  

The gravy tasted so good while cooking, you really didn't have to put sour cream in if you didn't want to.  

Tip: I cut the meat in strips when it was half thawed out for easier handing.

city:

None
text:
This was amazingly good!  I used sirloin and marinated in red wine for an hour.  Minced a clove of garlic to put in with the onion, using an  entire bunch of scallions (reserving about a third of them to add with the mushrooms at the end, and to use as garnish).  I used about 8 oz. of mushrooms, adding half during the simmer stage and the other half at the end.  I used sherry instead of white wine, beef bullion instead of broth, and kosher salt.  Used 1/3 c. + of sour cream, and about 3 tablespoons of cream cheese.  My only  complaint is not enough sauce.   We wanted more because it was so darned good!

text:
I have made this dish a few times and have decided this one is most like the one I remember my mother making when I was a child some 70+ years ago, the only changes I have made to make it "mine" is to use fresh sliced baby Bella mushrooms and 2 TBS of dry sherry at the finish.  Sometimes, I 'll add a teaspoon of Penzey's Tsarest Nights seasoning which gives it that hint of caraway which is so often used in Russian cooking.

Display Name:
jeff
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe but not really.  I used 1 lb of stew beef, which I seasoned and then marinated in red wine for about an hour. Browned the beef and removed. Then sautéd 1/2 a diced yellow onion and 2 large cloves of chopped garlic. Returned meat and added about 1 cup of unsalted beef broth. Dissolved 1TB each of flour and corn starch in 2 oz of beef broth and added to pan. Brought to boil then reduced heat to low, covered and cooked for about 1 hr. After hour added one 6oz can of mushroom pcs, 2 TB of sour cream and 1 TB of cream cheese. Cooked for about 5 mins as I finished cooking NO Yolk noodles. It was about the perfect amount for my wife and I. We both thought it was very good. I had been leery of the cream cheese hence only using 1 TB but it was all good. Thanks for giving me a starting place, as I said I made it but not really.

text:
I've made this a number of times now and it's always a crowd pleaser. Super simple and tasty the first day and even better the second. My only modification is taking the meat out to make the roux and sauce so I don't have to juggle sides of the pan. Add the beef back immediately after. I also like to sprinkle a small amount of paprika in at the end as well as on top along with the extra green onion for presentation.

text:
This is a near perfect Stroganoff recipe. I did use sweet onion instead of the whites of green onions. I added Worcestershire sauce with Dijon mustard. I used the white wine to deglaze the pan after I browned the beef and just  before I cooked the onions, garlic, and fresh mushrooms. I stirred the flour into the pan juices to make a roux, then added the beef broth and simmered for 45 min until thickened. I did add a little wine afterwards to thin the gravy a bit.I did not add cream cheese to the sour cream as this is very rich and creamy as it is. Turns out perfect every time.

region:

country:
None
text:
I used 2 cups Fusili pasta. I used AA sirloin beef stir fry strips. I marinated it in red wine for about 25 mins. I didn’t have onion so I used a bit of French Onion soup mix and stirred it with the meat and juices. I added 3 cloves of minced garlic. I took out the beef and put it aside. I added the can of beef broth let it boil and stirred in 1 tbsp starch and 1 tbsp flour. Once thickened and blended I added the beef back in and let it simmer for about 20 mins. I then added 2 heaping tbsp sour cream and 2 heaping tbsp herb and garlic cream cheese.

It was good but needed just a little more to make it really good. I used heavy cream because that's what I had but I do think sour cream would have been better. I used about 1/2 tsp nutmeg, fresh sliced mushrooms, added to the sauce about 20 minutes before it was finished, 4 cloves of diced garlic when I put the onion in and red wine instead of white. I also used more beef broth than the recipe called for as it thickened up quite a bit. I just added it as I thought necessary to end up with the consistency I thought it should be. I'd make it again with my modifications.

Make this when you have more than an hour to kill before you want to serve dinner

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really like the ingredients in this recipe, but every time I have made it in a pan, the meat turns out really tough.  I have found that if I sauté the meat as directed, place it in a slow cooker, then sauté the onions in butter until just before carmelized, add the flour, mustard and 1 cup beef stock to the pan and bring to a boil, then add it to the slow cooker and cook on low for about 5 hours, the meat is nice and tender.  I stir in sliced fresh mushrooms, sour cream and 2 Tbsp. red wine vinegar about 1 hour before serving and cook it on High.  Done this way, the whole dish is perfectly flavorful.  At our favorite Russian restaurant, they serve Beef Stroganoff with diced dill pickles and fresh dill weed on top.  I have started doing this when I serve this at home.  If you are a dill pickle lover, give this a try.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
24873405
Display Name:
GennyMac
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've loved Beef Stroganoff from my first taste in NY on business trip.  I love this recipe, but have given up on the skillet cause I end up making so much of it.

I now use a 4 qrt Soto pot.  I brown the meat in olive oil, constantly tossing it to ensure it browns consistently.  Then I toss in a whole onion, chopped, 2 cloves garlic minced, and about a cup or a bit more red wine.  I let that all cook down till there is very little fluid left, then sprinkle my flour over the whole mess and toss heavily to get the flour completely dissolved.  I've never had an issue with it clumping.  

I let that simmer just a bit to cook the flour taste out, then throw in the beef broth, etc.  I do use more sour cream and I have used cream cheese as well.  If I have ground chuck or even hamburger I need to use, I've thrown that in too.....but have to be careful about excess grease.

I cannot keep my peeps away from the stove with this one
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-01-02T22:22:53.96
helpfulCount:
0

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
this has become our staple strogonaff and my sons  favorite dinner!! I've made it numerous times tweaking it here and there. 
 First, I double up on the sauce. original recipe just isn't enough for us. I use fresh organic mushrooms and sautee them with sage and add at end with sour cream and wine. I add garlic to everything so that went in while cooking the meat and Worcestershire as it was simmering. I omit the mustard cuz I didnt have any on hand the first time and honestly.. WHAT is PREPARED mustard? used red onions cuz that's all I had and i didnt even bother doing the whole push the meat to the side thing lol. i cooked the meat, set it to the side, sauteed the onions, added broth and flour (whisking first in separate bowl to insure no clumping) and returned meat to the pan. I have not yet tried marinating in red wine... that will be next along with serving over mashed potatoes! bake up some good fresh bread and serve over egg noodles! ABSOUTLY HEAVENLY!!! Thank you for an amazing recipe!

text:
Some changes made: soaked meat in red wine for about 20 minutes, added the wine to the broth mixture afterwards. Used 2 tbsp of corn starch with 2 tbsp of Wondra flour instead of 4 tbsp flour. Also crushed a large garlic bulb and added while meat simmered. Used dried onion instead of all that onion, kids tend to be turned off with all the onion. At the end I used 4 tbsp of low fat cream cheese and whisked it into the sauce. Results were fantastic and very family friendly! Would make again.

text:
This stroganoff is easy to make and pretty tasty with a very mild flavor that the folks who don't typically like stroganoff will probably love and the ones who do love it will think it's different but tasty!  If you like it to have a lot more bite from the sour cream you will need to up the content to more like a cup. And for those who like a real powerful beefy onion flavor, you will need to add a package of onion soup/gravy mix. I cooked mine by the recipe but in my instant pot and it was very good. although you have to adjust how you cook it a tad.

text:
I used beef stew meat and sliced in about 1/4 inch slices.  I browned the meat in olive oil, removed and set aside, then added the onion and butter to skillet, then added fresh sliced mushrooms and some worstershire sauce and cooked mushrooms,  added back the beef and onions, and remaining ingredients.  I used beef consumme’ soup.  Everything else was the same and I simmered an extra 10 minutes.  Served over egg noodles and had left overs next day with rice.  It was excellent and will make again.

city:

text:
I made this for dinner to welcome my son home from the Navy. I read all the reviews and decided to incorporate some of them. I marinaded the beef in merlot for 2 hours, then dried it off before putting into the pan to brown. I did take the beef out of the pan before I put the onions in. I used fresh mushrooms and extra garlic cloves. The final count on garlic cloves was 4. I did add 1/3 Cup sour cream AND 4 Oz cream cheese at the end. I served it over mashed potatoes because my son doesn’t like egg noodles. The dish was so good there was silence at my dinner table for a few minutes while everyone ate up! He already requested this again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5496296.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made the stroganoff, just not so much like this recipe suggests.  I used homemade (seasoned) pasta, a bottom roast (half), and had no need for wine or any suggested Worcestershire sauce. A slow bake of the seared roast seasoned with powdered onion and garlic, Adobo, and pepper,  in a little beef broth, with an added yellow onion and chunked fresh mushrooms and added 3 minced garlic gloves, made for a flavorful broth that only needed thickening and a dab of sour cream. Added with the pasta infused with garlic and onion, had every bite equally enjoyable as the next. This was to be dinner, but lunch got the first bite. 

I'm sure this recipe would taste good as it's written,  but the stomach wants what the stomach wants, so I put a mild southern touch on this comfort food.

5

text:
My family loves this recipe! I made some minor changes and it turned out amazing! 1st, to save myself some time, I use the value packs of stew meat and cook it in small batches to get it cooked a little more quickly. 2nd, I like fresh mushrooms. So after I brown all the stew meat, i remove the meat frim the pan and I add 2 extra tbs of butter and cook one package of presliced button or baby Bella mushrooms for 2 mins or so or til lightly browned. I will remove the mushrooms and place the meat back in the pan and finish cooking the meat as directed in the recipe. Enjoy!

text:
I liked the steps of preparation. Logical and directions were easy to follow.
   I used a medium white onion instead of green onions.
   Instead of a can of beef broth I used a package of Lipton’s beef soup mix added to 2 c. of water which I think gave it a good flavor, and the additional liquid seemed to be necessary.
   I added a couple of shakes of worchestershire sauce for a bit of tang.  
   I used fresh mushrooms instead of canned which I sautéed in olive oil and added during the simmering time. 
   Didn’t have wine. Don’t know that it was missed.

userID:
5669115
Display Name:
Sportsmaven
isPro:

followersCount:

5
favoritesCount:
68
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4589466.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really very good but of course like so many I had to add and subtract.  First I used top sirloin I think it does better in this type of dish.  I did marinate it in white wine for two hours.  Dredged the meat in seasoned flour and browned.  Removed and sautéed a yellow onion in the drippings.  Added fresh mushrooms to the onions and when they were mostly cooked added garlic.  Deglazed the pan with a little more white wine (why not).  Added Worchester sauce for enhanced flavor.  I use beef stock and if the sauce is too thin then make a little roux.  When I make my noodles I cook them in beef stock as well.  This turned out yummy and my husband loved it too.  That is most important. Happy cooking!!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-02-12T01:08:55.86

userID:
3702488
Display Name:
Emily Reid
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
46
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4182147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since I don't have a giant skillet, I browned the beef strips a bit at a time, and used a second skillet to hold them while I sauteed the onions. Then again to hold the onions while I made the gravy.

I only used about half the amount of butter to brown the meat and onions. Then three more Tablespoons to make the roux for the gravy.

When the gravy was ready, I returned the beef and onions back to the original pan to simmer for about 45 minutes.

After 45 minutes, I used the second pan to sautee up some fresh mushrooms in that last Tablespoon of butter, instead of using canned. I added the wine to the mushrooms, and let that boil down for a minute or two. 

Used plain Greek yogurt instead of sour cream, and added it to the simmering gravy and goodness with the mushrooms. 

Turned out really well. Didn't feel like the butter was over powering, or that the wine thinned out the sauce too much. 

Delicious!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-01-31T02:33:33.057

text:
This is a fantastic recipe! I have made it a number of times and always thought it was slightly difficult to push the beef to one side of the pan while making the roux on the other, so I did what others had suggested and simply removed the beef and re-added later. Also, mixing the flour into the broth before adding to the pan was effective as well. I also added garlic as others mentioned but also added a heavy TBSP of Better Than Bouillon beef base. Incredibly flavorful and was a hit with the family!

443593
Display Name:
KLEONARD

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious!  I followed the advice of other reviewers and marinaded the beef in red wine for a few hours.  I also cooked the beef separately and also cooked the mushrooms separately and added them cooked at the end.  I completely forgot the mustard and it was still delicious.  I added cloves of garlic right before I made the sauce and added very little sour cream (due to my husbands preference).  Lastly, I omitted onions of any kind entirely, so I would appeal to my kids.  The one thing I learned after making it the first time is that it really does take a while to cook.  An hour wasn't enough for me.  You want the connective tissue to break down, and that took about 2 hours on a high simmer.  This makes a huge difference in the taste of this dish when you cook it long enough.
Everyone in my family loved it, I will be making this again and again, it's also company worthy as well!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I enjoyed the recipe, just a few things I changed.  I used a 2lb sirloin steak cutting it in very thin strips against the grain.  dusted the strips in flour and then salt and pepper put in 4TBSP of butter with a little Olive oil for 3-4 mins pulled out of the pan.  then in same pan sauteed 1cup chopped onions, 1 16oz sliced mushrooms with additional 2TB butter, 2 lg cloves garlic finely chopped.  cooked for 5 mins  then added 1 cup white wine till reduced then added 3 TBS of flour and cooked for 3 mins then added 3TBSP of tomato paste, still and add 1 15oz can of beef stock.  let thicken add 8oz sour cream and serve over noodles.

text:
Outstanding! Just like my Grandma used to make. Thank you!

Edit: I had no issues with any clumping. It's roux 101. A roux is a combo of fat and flour; equal amounts. The clumping occurs if not added in the order specified. It's supposed to be fat and flour, then liquid.  Enjoy!

userID:
8891063
Display Name:
CarolG
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
115
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am giving this a three star mostly because if you add wine to the dish in the end, that is all you will taste. Marinating the meat in the wine & then adding, or adding the wine with the beef broth & then simmering for at least an hour will give the sauce a deep, rich flavor. Just like spaghetti sauce or any sauce always simmer a sauce that has wine. Also, adding a few splashes of Worshire sauce is essential to the meat tasting very rich along with the wine. 

I always take out the meat after browning it, & I use sirloin steak. I add fresh garlic, fresh mushrooms, chopped yellow onion. Then I add beef bouillon soup, as much as 3 cans depending on how much meat I am cooking, & 1 can of French onion soup. I do add real butter, & chopped parsley & butter to my noodles before adding the stroganoff. I season the stroganoff with coarse black pepper, salt, onion powder, a touch of garlic powder, & two or three tablespoons of ketchup which I add to the sauce mixture before I simmer it. I always use a good white wine  & marinate the meat in it & add all of it to the sauce in the beginning. I add about a half cup of sour cream in the end. When completely done, I add a little chopped parsley which makes it look so nice. I may try using a little cream cheese with my sour cream next time as others have done, that sounds good. And I do thicken the sauce with flour mixed with some of the broth so it will be smooth.
This is a very special dish, that we eat once in awhile so this is not mean
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2017-12-14T11:50:36.8
helpfulCount:

text:
Good stuff! My changes make it a FIVE. Since the 1960's, my family has loved this recipe, with the following minor substitutions: fresh mushrooms rather than canned, consume rather than beef broth, regular onions with large chop rather than green onions, and 1/4 teaspoon of dry mustard rather than prepared mustard. We serve over buttered noodles, with steamed asparagus covered by hollandaise, and hot garlic bread to sop any gravy. Finish with Midwest style cheesecake, and you have the perfect meal!

text:
We liked this recipe. I browned the meat and put it in the crockpot with the chopped green onion (raw). Made the gravy on the stovetop and added sherry to that instead of white wine at the end. Poured over the meat in the crockpot. Cooked on low for 3 hrs, adding in fresh mushrooms during the last 30 minutes. Mixed in the sour cream before serving. I served this over egg noodles. The meat was tender and it was delicious!

text:
Why the cream cheese? I don't know what prepared mustard is so used wholegrain. Can't go wrong. Fried onion with salt and pepper, sautéed mushrooms. Lightly fried beef then added wine which I cooked off a little bit. Only put in 1 1/2 cups beef stock loads of garlic and worchershire. Brought to the boil then put in the oven for 1 and a half hours at 160 degrees Celsius. Before I added 1/4 cup each of cream cheese and sour cream it was AMAZING!!! The cream cheese killed it. Next time I will stick to sour cream only. Put less stock in it then you don't need cornflour.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used your recipe as a base to work with, read a lot of web comments about what is authentic or not, asked a pro cook I know in Canada who is Deaf and considering his own business, and made my alterations. 

I subbed white chopped onion for green. I used a large mushroom although something called cremelli mushrooms are said to be good as I didn't see any. Mushroom soup is fake others said so it is one reason I chose your recipe. Some said use white some say red, which confuses me because I'm no expert. So I grabbed at Whole Foods a cheap Pinot noir and used that. I used only a pinch of flour because wine my buddy told me thicken the stuff stuck to the bottom of the pan. He was right! So do not scrape clean your frypan before finishing! 

I had white pepper powder and I used good olive oil instead of butter to fry.  I love sour so besides real sour cream without stabilizers or gums to thicken it artificially, I threw in a little lemon juice to taste.

Many Russians say noodles are a no no.  But I'm American and I do what I like, so egg noodles it is! :D

I haven't had this since I was around 7. We were dirt poor and used a packet and sour cream. This recipe is nostalgic and don't have the gums and garbage they put i seasoning packets today.
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
4768316
Display Name:
Cheech Mc
isPro:

10

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making beef stroganoff for years and this is the basic recipe but if you add 1 can tomato paste, 2 large finely chopped dill pickles, 1 tbspn Worcestershire sauce and soak the beef in red wine 1hr minimum prior to browning then it's 10x better!! Of course add more garlic and I use a minimum of 2 cups beef broth and simmer all the ingredients except the beef ,on the stove together for about 5-8mins, after putting the beef to the side.  Then mix it all together in a French Oven and cook on 300 for 3-4 hrs. The key is that you need to start with enough liquid, so as to avoid adding beef broth throughout, because remember in the beginning when you carefully blended all those juices together? That extra 10mins wasn't for nothing. You can always thicken at the end when I add my flour right into the sour cream container before adding to the dish!
Review:

This is an easy to follow recipe and doesn't require much work. 
When I make this again I will make a couple of adjustments. I I'll eliminate the white wine. I did not care for the twangy flavor the wine added in the final product. It was good but I wished after I added it I hadn't. And I'll add a little more mustard next time. 
Overall with a few minor, personal tweaks this is very easy, tasty, hearty dish to serve to your family.

text:
So, so, so impressed! I went from "what do I do with leftover venison steak?" to "holy cow, I can't believe we just ate all of that!" in the matter of one hour. I sauteed the onions in the butter, threw in the chopped up steak, and added dried mushrooms and about 2 cans of broth and the mustard. I cooked it for about 45 minutes (Hey! I was hungry!) and then added a 4oz log of creamy goat cheese (we're sensitive to cow's milk here) and 1 Tbsp corn starch to thicken. That's it. I skipped the rest of the ingredients because the steak had been marinated, but WOW!!! This was seriously good.

text:
Very rich and a little on the salty side, next time I'll use unsalted butter and hope that works.  I followed beezlyS' advice with the cornstarch, mustard and Worcestershire sauce.  I marinated my meat in red wine and then after the beef stock to the cooked meat and veg, I threw that wine in just before letting it cook for 45 minutes.  I would recommend stirring your stew a couple times while it simmers.  Mine caramelized a bit, not too bad though.  My entire family devoured this dish and I will definitely make it again and again and again.  Oh! I also have a rosemary bush outside and took a sprig from that and put it in every step from marinade to serving.

text:
Delicious comfort food!  I made the recipe pretty much as written, except that I didn't have any white wine, so used red instead.  I used chuck, and after simmering for an hour it was a little chewier than I like it.  Next time I will either allow more time to simmer or slice it thinner than 1/2 inch, or use sirloin.  Maybe marinating it in the wine for a few hours would help to tenderize it, too.  I used fresh mushrooms, and added them to the simmer about halfway through rather than at the end.  I added a little more sour cream than the recipe calls for.  Great recipe -- thanks for sharing!

Served this with whole wheat egg noodles. I used my slow cooker/electric pressure cooker/browner (like a generic Instapot) to make this. I used olive oil instead of butter and whole wheat flour. text:
Used left over beef tenderloin when making this. I sauteed the onions a bit, then added the mushrooms and some minced garlic that I didn't measure, added the meat to heat it up.  Doubled the sauce so I added 4 tbls of corn starch to one can of condensed soup and 4 tbsp of flour to the other, stirred that in then added the mustard and Worcestershire sauce.  Cooked it a bit to thicken the sauce then added 1/3 cup cream cheese (doubled) and 1/3 sour cream  doubled. Served it over brown rice, the boys loved it, so good!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really great!  I marinaded the beef in garlic and some red wine, then when ready to cook, I cooked the beef (this would be great with ground beef too ), set aside and cooked chopped onion, in some butter (next time i would cook the mushrooms and onion together).  I dissolved the flour in the broth and then that was added to the skillet adding back in the beef.  There wasnt enough liquid so i added some water and a bit more wine so that the (fresh) mushrooms could cook down some.  At the end, I added about (1/3 c each for regular portion recipe), two heaping tbs of sour cream and two tbs of cream cheese (for half the recipe).  Also added 1/2 tsp of dijon mustard.  This was excellent served over noodles.  Next time though, id cook the mushrooms with the onions, and definitely no need to simmer for an hour!

country:
None
text:
My mother-in-law was a wonderful cook, her Beef Stroganoff was the best.  After a few very small changes, this recipe tops hers.  I mixed 1 Tbs. Worcestershire sauce with the 1 tsp. of mustard.  I substituted 2 Tbs. of corn starch for 2 of the 4 Tbs. of flour and I added 2 large cloves of minced garlic.  I sauteed 8 oz. of fresh mushrooms (sliced) in lieu of canned.  Thanks Donna for sharing a great recipe.  One last comment:  It is a little time consuming.  Next time I'll do some of the slicing in advance and even saute' the mushrooms earlier in the day.

country:
None
text:
Really good!  I made it w/ ground beef (actually bison) which I as described in first steps so I didn't need to simmer it for an hour- it would have dried out on my stove if I had.  I sauteed raw sliced crimini mushrooms with truffle salt and truffle oil and that gave it an extra flavor.  I also used low fat sour cream and you really don't need much if any butter if you want to be a little healthier.  It was really good. I served it over egg noodles, but my husband (who is watching his carbs) pulled out mostly meat/mushroom and felt I could have served just that.  That might be better for those watching carbs.  I bet you could throw in some raw spinach, cook it w/ mushrooms and include more good greens that way.  Yummy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading many, many reviews, I made this with the following changes:  I marinaded my beef strips in white wine and minced garlic for 2 hours before proceeding with recipe and omitted the addition of wine later in the recipe; I used chopped white onion in place of the green onion, I used fresh mushrooms in place of canned and sautéed them with the onion, I used 2 T flour and 2 T cornstarch, I added a 1/2 T of Worcestershire sauce to the mix, and I added 1/3 cup of cream cheese.  This is not a dish I'd make frequently as we really don't eat a lot of noodles or other carbs, but every now and then, this is a winner with the changes.  Very tasty!

SueCorvette

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm giving this 4 stars even tho I haven't actually made it yet because it is almost the same as my family recipe which we have loved for generations. The difference is I combine the flour, salt, pepper and garlic powder and dredge the beef in the flour mixture before browning. I, like others, brown the beef in batches. I also use a combination of butter and olive oil, adding more as needed. I use round steak and stick it in the freezer for a few minutes to make it easier for slicing (in strips against the grain)  I don't know what Chuck is, but we don't have that cut in Canada. Round is a (fairly) cheap cut and slowly simmering makes it so tender. I also use chopped yellow onions, adding them with the beef broth. We have always served it over rice and it is one of my go-to's for a fancy dinner.  Now that the kids are grown, I'm looking forward to trying this with wine. Sorry for the long post

text:
This was very good.  However adding the flour dry to the juices caused lumps.  Next time I make this I will dissolve the flour in some of the beef broth before adding it.  Also, I added the white wine and 2 can's of mushrooms along with the broth so everything cooked at one time.  I did not have green onions so I used part of a regular yellow onion and it was fine.  I added the sour cream at the end as suggested and served it over top of egg noodles.   Everyone including my picky 3 year old ate this and loved it.

I saved this to my favorites because I will definitely make this again!  I just made it for my daughter and son-in-law, and there wasn't a morsel left. Thank you for a great recipe!

I thought this was a very good basic recipe.  Like others, I used top sirloin and added 1/3 c cream cheese and 1/3 c sour cream. text:
Used a good chuck roast, cut off fat and gristle. Used dijon mustard and skipped the beef broth, using water instead. Added fresh mushrooms instead of canned. Used red wine instead of white. A bit of extra sour cream did nicely.  After browning, only cooked for about 20 minutes. One hour would dry the meat out too much for my liking.  The beef was very tender after 20 minutes, served on top of extra-wide egg noodles. Very good recipe.

userID:
7276971
Display Name:
blujnqueen
isPro:

31

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5211371.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really only modified the steps, not so much the ingredients.  I used very thin steak and omitted the butter altogether.  Reviewers suggested a few things, so I did as they did. I marinated the beef in 1/3 cup wine  with 1Tbsp of Worcestershire while I read up on several more reviews, and as I prepped the other ingredients.  In olive oil, I browned the meat together with the green onions & 2 garlic cloves. The wine with Worcestershire remained in the bowl I used, so I added 2 Tbsp of flour & 2 Tbsp cornstarch to that, dissolved it & added that mix to the meat/onions still in the skillet. I used 1/2 tsp concentrated beef broth (Superior Touch Better Than Bouillon Beef Base) & just added enough water as needed, then the sour cream at the end.  I served it over bow tie pasta.

text:
I made this as written and added a shake of garlic powder and Worcestershire. It was delicious, and I think it would have been fine without those additions. I read other reviews that said it had way too much butter. You need the butter for the 4Tbsp of flour in order to make the roux. You can't taste the butter as long as you are following the directions as written.  This was very quick prep time and I was able to do other things while it simmered. My kind of meal!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was a bit leery of the stated cook time, but I got a decent sized chuck roast and dove in. It's a surprisingly easy recipe, with most of my effort centered around trimming the meat. The chuck roast I got took a lot of effort to clean up, but the finished result was worth it.

I would guess it takes 10-15 minutes from the start of cooking to the 'simmer' phase, then just check on it every 10-15 minutes. The end result was tender and flavorful meat with a nicely balanced sauce. I served it over egg noodles and the family devoured it. I would say the recipe is for 6, and I didn't put in mushrooms.
Review:

userID:
3099652
Display Name:
poshlynne
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
182
favoritesCount:
522
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love beef stroganoff but my husband only tolerated it until now.  This was fabulous...amazing flavors and the chuck roast (who knew?!?) was so tender and delicious.  I cut the butter in half.   I chunky chopped a regular onion, instead of the green onions  I used 2 tablespoons of cornstarch and 2 of flour mixed in with the condensed beef broth before adding it to the pan.  Chopped up some garlic, about 4 cloves.  Added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire.  I did use a can of mushrooms but also used 2 portobello mushroom caps.  I upped the sour cream to 1/2 a cup and added 1/3 of a cup of whipped cream cheese.  I left out the white wine because I marinated the meat in red wine for about 30 minutes.  I didn't cook it all in the pan, I stink at that.  I flash cooked the meat.  Took it out, sautéed the onions, adding the mushrooms when the onions were about 1/2 done.  Added the garlic about 1 minute before the onions and mushrooms were good.  Then threw everything else in the pan (except sour cream and cream cheese) and covered and simmered for just over an hour...adding the sour cream and cream cheese off heat.  Amazing.

text:
Made this with Beezlys adaptations: marinade meat in red wine, add Worcestershire sauce and cream cheese. Yellow onion instead of green. The only other thing that needed changing was that 4 tbsp flour was too much for the amount of beef broth. It was really thick and goopy. But it needed more sauce than the amount of beef broth made. By the time I thinned it out with additional broth it was right thickness and quantity. Probably used twice or more the amount of broth

text:
I would never use chuck roast or steak unless I ground it.  It tends to be tough even with lengthy cooking.  Also the true flavor of stroganoff is destroyed with wine.  It overpowers the sour cream which by itself at the end is quite adaquate to give a delicate and delicious flavor.  Also be aware that use of canned broth leads to sodium overload.  This recipe was completely inedible.  I do not recomment this at all.

text:
This was so good and everyone loved it. I quadrupled this because we had a lot of meat and so many people here and I wanted some leftovers. I did two things slightly different.  I used half the amount of sour cream and then half cream cheese per some reviews to make it creamer. It was delicious. The only other thing I did differently is I cooked it in a pressure cooker and it was done much faster and really tender. I will definitely make this again.

userID:
12289371
Display Name:
Pixie
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one was a drool recipe. What's amazing is that I was distracted while making it, botched the directions, and it still was great. So....for those wondering how this is possible, I think a really good recipe can be messed up, and come out shining. I did marinade the beef (in my case, sirloin strips) for two hours in apple juice (no wine, but it is a great substitute), 1 Tbs Worcestershire sauce, touch of black pepper, salt, and garlic powder. Then drained before frying. I mixed the whole sauce at one time (I told you I was distracted). 4 Tbs of cornstarch in 1/4 of the beef broth--let it sit after mixing. The rest of the sauce ingredients went into another bowl to mix--including the sour cream. Well, I WAS distracted.....Despite a bit of worry, I did add the garlic and 1/3 cup cream cheese (I had whipped). So into the sauce mix went garlic, cream cheese, black pepper, salt, beef broth, mustard (spicy brown), few drops of Worcestershire, touch more apple juice, and sour cream. Once that mixed, I dropped in the mixed cornstarch/broth mix. I heated 2 Tbs of butter, and slammed in the beef to brown. And, in a small frying pan, 1 Tbs butter and the maya sweet onion. Once cooked, I dropped the meat and onions into a strainer to drain. I left the meat drippings, and added the sauce, heating to boil, and cooked it down. In came the meat and onions; one hour simmer, and perfect. Delicious recipe, and came through in the clinch of my wandering.

userID:
1010175
Display Name:
TLRINEY
isPro:

19
favoritesCount:
147
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe, and I modified it to work with hamburger. No doubt it will taste even better with better meat, but I had the burger on hand. I followed the suggestions of onion (I used 1/4 red), and garlic (about 4-5 fresh cloves). Here's how I made it, but I'm sure it can be done many different ways: browned the burger. In separate pan, cooked mushrooms, onion and garlic with some olive oil. Threw some wine in there, because I felt like it. After they cooked down, I added it to the burger. Then I made a roux with some butter and flour, and added the broth to that (more wine too, OBVIOUSLY :), cooked it until it thickened, and then added that to the meat. After it was thickened, I added the cream cheese, dijon mustard and sour cream. Oh - so GOOD. I actually added more mustard to my plate, because I like that flavor, but you can add more or less depending on your preference.
Review:

userID:
9370166
Display Name:
Laura Hamilton
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4

0

100

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1199407.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
To die for!  I make a huge pot roast the night before I make this, and use the leftovers for this.  I serve it over egg noodles.  I don't usually buy wine for it, though; I just use extra beef broth.  We don't drink wine, so the rest of the bottle would be wasted.  Still amazing!  EDIT:  I've made this recipe many times, and I've added a few tweaks to it.  Green onions are great, but if you don't have them, white are just fine if you saute them beforehand.  You can use fresh mushrooms if you do the same thing.  I add a little extra flour because I like my sauce thicker.  I've used beef bouillon cubes and water in a pinch on nights I've run out of beef broth.  And I added the white wine for the first time tonight.  Although it tastes good without it, it goes on up to the next level with it!  Good over potatoes as well as egg noodles.

text:
My family loves this recipe! The only changes I make are to use a package of fresh, sliced mushrooms instead of the canned mushrooms. I cook them in the beginning with the onions (I usually use 1/2 of yellow onion, instead of the green onions as well). I also like to add a couple cloves of fresh garlic in with the onions & mushrooms and some dried basil with the salt & pepper. However, even without making any changes at all, everyone devours this dish & goes back for more :) To make the recipe really easy & to save time, I've also substituted ground beef for the chuck roast. Just brown the beef in the beginning, along with the onions & mushrooms, then follow the remainder of the recipe as is. This eliminates the hour of cooking time & dinner is ready in less than 15 minutes! Thanks, Donna, for a fabulous recipe!

text:
Yummy!  My whole family enjoyed it! I used leftover roast beef and left out the wine because I didn't have any. I also followed BEEZLY's suggestion and subbed in some cream cheese for the sour cream.  I put the beef broth and flour in a jar and shook it so I wouldn't have lumps. I also used fresh mushrooms because we like them and they were on sale.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I thought this was great.  The only issue I encountered was that I had to cook the beef for a lot longer than I was expecting.  It took an hour and 40 minutes for it to be tender enough to want to eat.  Maybe the difference between a gas vs. electric (which is what I have) stove for "simmering"?  I marinated the beef in red wine, worcestershire sauce, chopped garlic, salt and pepper for 7 hours.  I used a can of Campbell's french onion soup plus a little beef stock, half a yellow onion plus 2 scallions, and first sauteed the onions separately before adding after the flour was stirred in with the beef.  I left out the mushrooms altogether as I don't like them.  Delicious!

text:
This was a very easy recipe to follow especially for a novice cook. It turned out great. I skipped the wine because I did not have any. I was also 2 oz short on broth and used 1.5 lbs of beef. I added a a little extra sour cream....amazing. If I do it again, I am going to cut back on the butter to make it a bit  healthier. I am also going to try it with organic filet or sirloin. I did not stir it the whole time it was simmering so it separated and I had to try to get the sauce together again. I simmered it until the meat was cooked, not the full hour. In the recipie. Leftovers were great!!!

Fantastic as is. I skipped the egg noodles and served with mashed potatoes. Display Name:
arnot77

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My entire family loved this and everyone asked for seconds, including all 5 kids (all under 10)!! There were a few things I did different mainly because I didn't have all ingredients. I used ground sirloin, put in bowl after browning. Added a tbl of butter and sauteed the onion (I used 1/2 of a white one), 2 tbl minced garlic and freah mushrooms. Once all the water cooked out of mushrooms, I added beef back in, seasoned with salt and pepper then added almost 2 cups of broth(Made with bullion cubes and water) with 2 tbl of corn starch mixed into broth. Once it thickened I added stone ground mustard, 1/3 cup of sour cream and about 1/3 of a cup of cream cheese. Stirred til smooth. I seasoned with lots more pepper, garlic powder and paprika. I served it over macaroni noodles...definately a keeper!

text:
My mother made stroganoff when I was growing up. I loved it. Have not had it in years. This was pretty close. I did make a few changes. 
- Used fresh mushrooms and a whole onion. Sauted at the begining in a little olive oil and garlic and then set aside while I browned the meat.
- Used Sirloin because that is what I had on hand.
- Added some of the wine early to simmer with everything else and added the rest with the Sour cream at the end.

Could have used just a touch more mustard.

Will defintely make this again....the family ate it up.

text:
This was excelent! I used venison instead of beef because I wanted to get rid of some in our freezer. Did not taste gamey at all! 

The only thing I did differently is I used fresh mushrooms instead of the canned and I cooked them with the onions then deglazed with the pan with the wine. I also used olive oil instead of butter to make it healthier. And I used corn starch instead of flour and mixed it with half the broth before I poured it in the pan to avoid lumps.

Very very good!! Thank you!!

Great!!! My picky teenager had two plates full.  I used the ingredients as written, with a few additions, switches because I did not have some things.  Cooked the onions and mushrooms with a little butter.  Removed them from the pan, added the meat.  Once the meat is browned, remove.  Made a slurry and added it to the beef stock, mustard and Worcester sauce, bring to a boil then add all the onions, mushrooms and meat back into the pan.

text:
Excellent recipe!  I used leftover steak that was cooked rare and I think that dramatically impacted the tender results we got.  I also increased the beef boulion to 2 cans and increased the sour cream to 3/4 cup.  We only simmered the meat 25 minutes total after we created the sauce and it was great.  If you start out with good meat that is slightly precooked, you don't need to simmer it the whole time.  My mother in law even raved about the meal, so, if she liked it, trust me, everyone will love it!  Enjoy!

text:
Fantastic recipe!  By far the best beef stroganoff recipe and so easy to prepare.  I added a 1/4 c. of red wine instead of the white wine.  It thinned the sauce a little bit, but I could thicken the sauce with a little water and flour until it was the right consistency.  I also added about 1/3 c. of chopped red onion instead of the green onion, 1/2 t. of crushed garlic, 1 t. of dried parsley and 1/2 t. of worcestershire sauce.  My teenage son, who scrutinizes everything I make, had three servings.  Definitely a keeper recipe!

For the sake of economy, I use stew meat (already chopped, and it tends to be cheaper). I also find it's just as good whether you use wine or not. I also sautee the onions and mushrooms at the beginning and allow them to cook with the meat. Definitely going to be made again and again!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I got two hi-5's for this one---one from hubby and one from myself!  Took someone's comment to cut the butter to one tablespoon.  My sous chef (hubby while I went to get my nails done) cut the meat in chunks rather than strips so it took about two hours to cook but that made the anticipation delightful.  I used white wine (by mistake and early in the preparation) instead and it was just fine. I initially was leary because the meat doesn't really "brown".  It rather kind of steams because of moisture and even though I was using a large dutch oven pot, I felt like I didn't have a lot of room when I was stirring in the flour but every thing went just fine.  Just had to work on slowly mixing in the broth and flour - like making a white sauce.  The absolute necessary final and deal maker was the sour cream--it brought it all together flavor wise and visually.  Some hearty Pennsylvania Dutch noodles, Corn and Butternut Squash (Paula Deen recipe that I decided not to use corn in---yummy) and mini buttermilk biscuits)and life was good this Sunday night at the Kneer's.  Dog was bummed though because he could not have these rich leftovers - only us - and plenty of them!

text:
I followed the recommendations of many others -- marinated the beef in (white) wine for 2 days, added 1T garlic, 1T worcestershire, sauteed fresh mushrooms, 1/2 block cream cheese, etc.  However I still thought this was just okay and the meat was tough.  Next time I'll use red wine and a better cut of beef (sirloin).  I might also try cooking it in the crock pot for several hours to break the beef down more.  Compared to other stroganoff recipes out there, this has good enough bones that it's worth trying out again with the modifications above.

This was VERY good.  Although, I would not cook the beef "quickly".  This made it tough.  Slow cook the beef to about medium-rare and then proceed with the recipe in order to make the beef tender.  All in all though, this was a winner at my house!

text:
Minor changes based on earlier feedback. Added chopped garlic along with green onion. Added Worstershire along with beef broth. Cooked up canned, sliced mushrooms along with beef for 1hr. 1/3 C cream cheese & 1/3 C. sour cream added at the end. After browning the meat, removed it from the pan allowing the broth and disolved flour to soak up the pan juices - meat then returned for 1hr simmer.

text:
Just what I was wanting, and probably my 61 yr old mom's recipe that I ate growing up!  I made some adjustments though to the original recipe. 1) Didn't have beef broth so I improvised with 3 bullion cubes disolved in the same amount of recommended liquid. 2) I did use yellow onion, garlic, and equal amounts of sour cream and cream cheese, and 3) I marinated my beef (stew meat was what I had on hand) in some red wine for only about 30 min and still added a white wine in the sauce.  Drawbacks, it was so good I wish I had more sauce.

My family LOVES this dish! I followed suggestions others posted by adding white onions and fresh mushrooms. I've made it several times and I find it's best without the wine. Makes the sauce to thin and runny. I also tried using less butter and light sour cream and it was still great. Going to try nonstick cooking spray next time as some users suggested. Also going to try Fage 0% nonfat greek yogurt instead of sour cream. It's so smoothe and creamy and I think it should be even better than sour cream. Thanks for the excellent recipe!

text:
We have tried so many Stroganoff recipes and finally found the one.  I did make minor changes so I could use ingredients I had on hand.  I used sirloin tips but will use the chuck next time.  I also used fresh mushrooms and about half a large yellow onion.  I marinated the sirloin for about a half hour in white wine and then did not add any at the end.  I did add 1/3 c low fat cream cheese at the end with the 1/3 c. low fat sour cream.  I also used 2.5 ounces of butter to make it a little leaner.  Delish!!!

text:
This is lovely.  Aside from pushing the meat and then the onions off to one side - which seems difficult - I don't change a thing.  I eyeball ingredients, but close enough.  I prefer to use fresh mushrooms.  Also, I use fat-free sour cream, which tastes almost as good.  I use half the butter, which may make a difference, but not enough for an every-day meal -- for guests, I might use the full amount, as well as "fatty" sour cream to bring this to a more rich flavor.  Overall, if my family likes it, it wins.  One of these days, I plan to experiment with cayenne as an addition.  Who knows?

text:
This was very good.  I used regular onions instead of scallions, but other than that, I followed the directions as stated.  The only problem that I had was that I didn't have enough juices to stir the flour into, so I had some lumps.  But, that can be easily fixed next time.  The white wine really made the dish -- it didn't overpower it, it just added a nice subtle flavor in the background.  I just used cooking wine, but I bet it'd be even better with the real thing.  My boyfriend, who loves the usual way I make stroganoff (I didn't use a recipe, just threw stuff together), was disappointed when he realized I wasn't making it the "normal" way.  But, he seemed to really like it and I know I did  P.S.  I was thrown off by the picture.  It looks like that cook used ground meat and no sour cream.

text:
This was so tasty, great recipe!! I did change it around a bit, I took the advice of other members and let the meat marinade in the wine. I used red wine instead of white and I also used extra lean ground beef because it's what I had on hand. I added galic while cooking the onions, then added 1 tbsp of Worcestershire sauce after adding the broth; I also added 1/2 tsp of dry Tarragon & 1/4 tsp on Nutmeg...it came out great!! We had the leftovers for lunch today and it was just as good as last night!! Will definitely make this again!! Thanks for the great recipe!!

I used to see Beef Stroganoff all the time at my uni cafeteria, and I would look askance when I saw other students eating it.  I think I had it once on a transpacific flight because the other choice was fish.  Never eat fish on a plane.  But I decided to make it because my BF said he liked it and this recipe got such great reviews. I regret it--it was an unappetizing looking, bland pap.  It belongs in a college cafeteria.  It truly baffles me why it's rated so highly.

userID:
1961680
Display Name:
Rachel M.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
3
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
54
favoritesCount:
298
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/72.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family really liked this.  I did make changes (I always do), so here goes.  First, I halved the recipe and used a sliced top round steak for the meat.  I used about a tablespoon of ghee (clarified butter) in lieu of the butter to prevent burning, and I used high heat for the initial meat searing.  I took another reviewer's advice, and plated the meat after the browning, and I used a white onion instead of the green ones.  I also added fresh mushrooms after the onions started to soften.  I didn't have condensed beef broth, so I reduced some regular broth with some red wine in the pan with the onions and mushrooms before putting the beef back in to simmer.  I put in a little garlic powder, and used cornstarch mixed with a little broth instead of flour since I didn't have pan juices from the high heat.  Skipped the white wine 'cause of the red wine reduction.  Served over buttered egg noodles, and my family really liked it.  I think it's pretty versatile, too.
