text:
This is a good basic recipe and luckily, some of the other reviewers gave some great advice.  I too added 1/3 cup cream cheese and it made it nice and creamy.  Also, didn't have canned mushrooms, but always have fresh ones at the ready, so I sliced and sauteed some.  Nice addition.  I also added 1 tsp garlic powder, a TBS of paprika at the very end and a dash of Worcestershire sauce to pick up the flavor.  My family really loved it.  I used leftover prime rib from our New Years Day dinner, so I didn't have to simmer as long - about 40 minutes.  I actually didn't pay attention and put in the sour cream and cream cheese at the beginning of the simmer and it still turned out delicious.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have a few of the ingredients on hand, so since I was making it just for two, I figured I could tweak it a little.  I used about a cup of Tyson  frozen precooked seasoned beef strips, 1 T cornstarch mixed with 1 T Worcestershire sauce, 7 T of half-and-half instead of the cream cheese/sour cream base, 7.5 T of water, 1/2 a yellow onion, 2 T butter, 1 oz of canned sliced mushrooms, salt to taste, and a grinding of freshly ground black pepper to taste.  I served it over cooked egg noodles, and it was pretty good.  My DH didn't complain.  :)

The Bunny Chef

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/69415.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
There are so many stroganoff recipes on here that I just picked one, and this was it!  I used 3/4 pound lean ground beef instead of the other meat, fresh mushrooms, normal white onion, added garlic and 3 T Worcestershire sauce, and used about 3/4 cup light sour cream.  I just cooked the meat, onions, mushrooms and garlic together, stirred in the wine and let it cook off a bit, then poured in the broth, Worc. sauce, pepper and mustard and let it simmer, covered, while the egg noodles cooked.  After the noodles were done, I mixed 2 T flour with 3 T milk and stirred it into the boiling sauce, let it cook a couple minutes then removed it from the heat and stirred in parsley and the sour cream.  This way, it was very quick.  We liked it pretty well, it made 4 servings.  I think 4 T flour would have been way too much and it definitely needed at least 3/4 cup sour cream, if not a bit more.  I'm sorry I messed with your recipe so much, but I really liked the outcome and was glad for the guide!  Thanks!

text:
My husband and I love this stroganoff recipe!!!  We make it on special occassions and it never fails...  We use a really good wine (though inexpensive), like a Vovrey or Riesling, good dijon mustard, and the last time we made this we used baby portabella mushrooms.  If I don't have scallions on hand, I just use regular white onions and cook them a little longer.  Also, instead of a beef chuck cut, we use a sirlion.  It cuts the cooking time down.  YUM!  Thanks for the great recipe.

I felt this recipe to be rather average. It's kind of a simple everyday recipe suited for the average home cook as opposed to being more of a chef creation. I can see where some of the modifications made by other reviewers would make this taste better and have a better consistancy. One note, I found this recipe under "Low Carb" recipes. As soon as you serve it over either rice or pasta the low carb aspect is gone! So for those of you that found it the way I did, watch out for those hidden empty carbs in the pasta or rice you might use.

This recipe was a hit, especially after a cool, brisk day.  I used sliced sirloin tip steaks and I had to use a can of french onion soup because I was out of cond beef broth. The steaks seemed to yield a little less desirable amount of juice so I then added a cup of beef granule mixed with water. I was out of white wine so I used a cup of champagne that I let sit for a bit to un-bubbly. Mom-In-law loved it too! I served it over egg noodles.

Delicious!!!  I sautéed the mushrooms and regular white onions with garlic.  Added sliced top sirloin steak and partially browed it. text:
This was good, but I would make a couple changes.  I agree with another reviewer that it needs to simmer closer to 2 hours to make the meat tender.  Also, I used 2c of stock (that's what size I had) and it worked well since I simmered it longer.  Next time I will dissolve the flour in the stock because it went lumpy added to the pot.  My husband doesn't like wine flavour, so I didn't put it in at all.  However, it was very flavourful and with this bit of "tweeking" I will definately make again.

I am retracting my previous review! I don't know what I did before, but this time it was much better. I used sirloin instead of chuck, sauteed it, then removed the meat to do the onions. I carmelized the onions with some minced garlic. I used homemade broth and added the meat back in for the simmering part. I also used fresh mushrooms and about 3 oz cream cheese to make it a little creamier. Served over noodles. Good comfort food, but too fattening for everyday. A keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is wonderful.  I had 4 pounds of stew meat, so I used that instead of the roast.  Also, I did not have beef broth, so I used beef base, made 2 1/2 cups of strong broth.  I did not add the salt.  Canned soups, base or boullion normally have a high sodium content, so adding any additional salt makes the dish too salty for us.  Also, I took the advice from one of the other reviews and added a few shakes of worcestershire sauce when I added the wine.  My family really liked this and I'm sure I'll make again.  They were fighting over who would take the leftovers for lunch!

This was delicious.  As did some others, I used round steak instead of chuck roast, and I replaced green onion with 1 regular onion.  Omitted the wine that I didn't have, and of course used fresh mushrooms, since canned are nasty and wrong.  Overall, it was really nice, and I could see adapting it to your crock pot as some others did... it would be even more tender.  A fair bit of work, but I'll be making this again- it was a hit!

text:
I loved this recipe, and so did my husband, who normally does not care too much for stroganoff.  He had two huge helpings at supper and is looking forward to the leftovers.  I did not have condensed beef broth on hand, so I used 3/4 of a can of Swanson's prepared beef broth with a bit of beef boullion shaken into it.  I also added about 5 shakes of Worchestershire Sauce right before I added the sour cream and wine.  Excellent.
